name: Crack'n'Hack
description: %CONTACT% from %COMPANY% called us today. They accidentally deleted their %PW_APPLICATION% passwords and need some cracking power.
onSuccess: Fortunately, they only used password shorter than 8 digits.
onFail: You stress their %PW_APPLICATION% protection with brute force, but after days you give up.

name: Security awareness lecture
description: Prof. %CONTACT%, head of %TOWN% %UNIVERSITY% asked you to give a lecture on security awareness.
onSuccess: It was great. Your demonstration of an attack on a %WEBSERVICE% really kicked ass.
onFail: The lecture was a complete disaster. Prof. %CONTACT% will probably not invite you again.

name: IT security lecture
description: Mister %CONTACT%, CEO at %COMPANY% in %TOWN% wants you to give a lecture on IT security in cooperation with the %TOWN% %UNIVERSITY%.

name: Best standard
description: The %TOWN% %UNIVERSITY% develops a new %SOFTWARE% and needs your help for implementing a %WEBSERVICE% featuring the latest security standards.
onSuccess: The new %WEBSERVICE% now implements the ISO 27000 standard and it's rocksolid.

name: Homefront
description: The guy next door, %CONTACT_M%, has a barking dog that really upsets you. Hack his %PW_APPLICATION% as payback.
onSuccess: His the password of his %PW_APPLICATION% actually was 'abc123'. Shame if someone changed it.
onFail: You tried a brute force attack using a dictionary of the most common passwords but everything failed. His %PW_APPLICATION% is secure for now.

name: C'mon Honey
description: The %TOWN% %INSTITUTION% frequently gets hacked by some bad guys. Install a honeypot in their IT system to catch those script kiddies.
onSuccess: You setup a sandboxed server with some fake data that looks like an easy target. In fact, every access is logged and carefully analysed. Two day later the fish gets caught in the net.

name: You, Robot
description: %COMPANY%, a smart home equipment manufacturer has been hijacked. All it's products are now part of a botnet. You need to wipe the malware and find the companies security leak.

name: Memeful intermezzo
description: The monitoring screens at %COMPANY% suddenly started to display some dank memes. CEO %CONTACT% turns to you in desperate need of help.
onSuccess: You did it! They were using Win XP and an old Flash version vulnerable to man in the middle attacks. Of course you saved the dankest memes for your private collection.

name: Dayly bread
description: You are hired for holding a security audit at a %COMPANY% facility in %TOWN%. Hack into their %PW_APPLICATION% to raise security awareness.

name: Catch a ride
description: The %COMPANY% motor company is evaluating the security of their cars electronic key system. Implement a new technique to complement it.
onSuccess: You intercept the keys radio signal and copy it onto a duplicate you soldered last night. How about a new BMW?
onFail: The keys feature an advanced cryptography algorithm you can't bite through.

name: You have no power here
description: The %TOWN% %INSTITUTION% organizes a competition for hackers to find security vulnerabilities in their IT system.
onSuccess: You won the competition! After dropping some USB sticks with the exploit code it only took hours until you could control the test system. Piece of cake since they are still running on XP.

name: %TOWN% tech festival
description: You have the opportunity to present your company at the %TOWN% tech festival. Gather together some cool gadgets and choreograph them with custom software.

name: Censorship is [CENSORED]
description: %COMPANY% and the %TOWN% %UNIVERSITY% are cooperating to develop an open-source anti censorship software to support free journalism in %COUNTRY%. Help improving their protocol with some extra manpower.

name: Rainbow shield
description: %COMPANY% hosts a %WEBSERVICE% that has been jammed by frequent DDOS attacks. You need to identify the origin of the threat and implement a robust counter mechanism.
onSuccess: The attack has been routed across the planet but you could track them to a command and control server in %COUNTRY%.
onFail: Seems like there is no distinct attack pattern you can focus on. The attackers pay much effort in hiding their identity.

name: Fixing potholes
description: %COMPANY% has problems integrating a new %SOFTWARE% into their %WEBSERVICE%.
onSuccess: Easy Peasy. This %SOFTWARE% is absolutely amazing.
onFail: This %SOFTWARE% and their %WEBSERVICE% must be written in gibberish++. After days of nonsense you give up.

name: Golden Age of Piracy
description: The %TOWN% %UNIVERSITY% spin-of %COMPANY% launches an innovative %SOFTWARE%. You are asked to audit their piracy protection system.
onSuccess: Wow, this tech is amazing! Now those pirates are gonna have a hard time.
onFail: Somehow you missed that obvious vulnerability. The %SOFTWARE% was cracked hours after release.

description: You got a job offer at the %TOWN% film studios for a supernumerary role as an evil super hacker. Don't forget to bring some impressive equipment.
onSuccess: It's doubtful that this movie will receive much attention but at least the villain is convincing.
onFail: In front of the cameras you suddenly become stage fright and have to leave the set. Embarrassing!

name: Gossip factory
description: Rumors tell that the %WEBSERVICE% hosed by %COMPANY% uses an outdated HTTPS protocol that allows session hijacking. Scout a viable attack scenario.
onSuccess: You created a script that intercepts data sent to the %WEBSERVICE% and may insert any kind of code. You sell your exploit profitably on the darknet.
